I recently received an invitation to join the Motoko community, and I accepted because I believe it's about fostering unity within the ICP community. We all share the same passion, and being part of Motoko Doodles, we deeply respect Motoko Ghosts and its creator. From the outset, we've emphasized that the inspiration extends to the entire community, not just us.

Now, onto the issue at hand: why are some Motoko members becoming aggressive towards Doodles? Art is subjective. If you appreciate it, you engage, if not, you move on, without targeting creators. Whether Motoko Doodles is officially recognized or not, for us, it is 100% official. Dismissing other art forms until Dfinity creates and endorses them seems limiting to the creative spirit of the ICP community.

Addressing pricing, our success in sales demonstrates significant community interest. We've been transparent about our team not profiting from Doodles. We've upheld our promise by refraining from holding or selling our marketing doodles or purchasing new ones.

Lastly, a note to <@1041679912416837683> and <@909153099027972117>: we haven't targeted or harmed anyone in the ICP community. Let's support each other rather than spreading negativity.

Also, thank you <@1197505314887585852> for appreciating our promotions. We're committed to maintaining our hard work and dedication.

referenced_message.content:
The current status is:

- Still no confirmation that icrc-37, the standard for approve & transferFrom, will be be supported before the canisters are blackholed and cycles costs are transferred to the community. 

*It was indicated earlier that it wouldn't be added, current status seems to be: "may be a good idea"*

- Still no access to repository that others have been given access to 8mnths ago.

- Still just a half-explanation (with no contract addresses) for pulling registry. 

*The notion that we would put heavy strain on the canisters is wrong. We build performant indexers and actually take a lot of strain off the IC the way we cache it, it doesn't have to be realtime. Also, a central indexer that everyone depends on from the team is easy to abuse (insider sniping, etc...)*

So far it's been a lot of words, I don't want to keep bothering the group with a bunch of unnecessary back and forth, what we need to see is a bit of action to want to want to get back on the train.

content: Completely agree. Doodles have achieved significant success in the last 30 days and are continuing to grow. From the very beginning, when Bobby first mentioned the Motoko DAO, we expressed our support. Doodles are prepared to contribute and eager to earn your support.

I understand the sentiment a lot of people are holding, but I think we need to consider the position we‚Äôre in; we‚Äôre asking people to submit their projects to work with the DAO. 

It might be beneficial to be less critical of existing (on trajectory to be successful) projects, as they already have a segment of community support, and more critical towards upcoming projects that don‚Äôt align themselves with the DAO; ex, Motoko Monsters. 

I completely agree that if the DAO is going to be backing a project in any capacity, there should be a quid pro quo exchange - the community shouldn‚Äôt simply be blinding supporting because the Motoko named is attached. 

This should be an exchange - the project requesting support should be able to offer something equivocal in value to the support they‚Äôre requesting from the community

I recently received an invitation to join the Motoko community, and I accepted because I believe it's about fostering unity within the ICP community. We all share the same passion, and being part of Motoko Doodles, we deeply respect Motoko Ghosts and its creator. From the outset, we've emphasized that the inspiration extends to the entire community, not just us.

Now, onto the issue at hand: why are some Motoko members becoming aggressive towards Doodles? Art is subjective. If you appreciate it, you engage, if not, you move on, without targeting creators. Whether Motoko Doodles is officially recognized or not, for us, it is 100% official. Dismissing other art forms until Dfinity creates and endorses them seems limiting to the creative spirit of the ICP community.

Addressing pricing, our success in sales demonstrates significant community interest. We've been transparent about our team not profiting from Doodles. We've upheld our promise by refraining from holding or selling our marketing doodles or purchasing new ones.

Lastly, a note to <@1041679912416837683> and <@909153099027972117>: we haven't targeted or harmed anyone in the ICP community. Let's support each other rather than spreading negativity.

Also, thank you <@1197505314887585852> for appreciating our promotions. We're committed to maintaining our hard work and dedication.
